job_title: Senior DevOps Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: I have found IBM a great place to work. I've been here 8 years now and have had great professional (technical) and personal growth in that time. I have been able to move around teams to find the right fit, each time learning new things that have made me a better engineer. I have (most of the time!) felt supported to try new things, safe in the knowledge that if it failed that it is the cost of innovation. There is also a great work/life balance. Of course there is as much work there as you want and I have spent many evenings working late when I felt it was important to do so - never at the insistence of a manager or colleague. At the same time, when I needed support for my personal life (children, illness etc.) it was always forthcoming along with compassion and a human touch.
cons: It is a big ship, very slow to turn. The internal bureaucracy can be frustrating, and communicating across teams can be little slow/difficult. The pros outweigh the cons in my experience YMMV!

pros: Flexibility, stability and good salary depending of the position.

pros: For me, up to this moment, IBM is the best employer. There are lots of opportunities for career development, not only are you encouraged to expand your skill set, you actually have a target of at least 40 hours per annum spent learning new skills :) The work/life balance is the best I've found up to date, and very hard to beat. Payment is on par or better than the market. To top it off, at least on my line of work there is no hard requirement to return to office. This is very important for me. However, colleagues that wish so, are welcome to office at any time.

review_title: A L4 Apprentice Overview of IBM as an IBMer in the first 6 months
job_title: Software Test Engineer in Hursley, England
pros: When I joined in June 2022 as part of IBM Consulting, it was the biggest embarkment I think I will ever make in the next 10 years. Being here now six months has made me learn so much and in so little time, so I have to just bullet point my top 8: 1. The opportunities for personal growth and future prospects 2. The warmness and kindness of literally everyone I've met in IBM is the most positive virus going round 3. My opportunity to expand my network on LinkedIn with hundreds of other IBMers and senior leading figures in other companies too 4. Flexible working and truly understanding people and clients (if you have a good reason to not be able to travel to client site, then its perfectly fine) 5. The diversity and inclusion is amazing which allows all to grow as an individual and professionally 6. The experiences and opportunities are never-ending and company benefits are second-to-none you just wouldn't find elsewhere in other large tech firms 7. Your peers and management have always got your back and the best intentions in mind 8. If you are a school leaver starting just like I was (I had my final A-Level exam 3 days prior to starting) and worried about the age gaps and experience gaps, this is nothing to be worried of. You will quickly learn only from the best and learn far more than you think.
cons: There are not many cons I can think of, just only these to take into consideration as a Level 4 Apprentice (UK): 1. Balancing your day-to-day work tasks on top of your apprenticeship learning can easily get too overwhelming (but there is support and help with that) 2. Your work-life balance can too easily go into the air especially as a young person with often (assumed) little responsibilities to take care of (but for those who do or are getting tired of constant travel for instance are able to take a break in their favour) 3. Reviews, reviews, reviews, and paperwork. It is no surprise there can be a fair amoun of paperwork involved in any job, you aren't taking life seriosuly if you think there can be a minimal or no amount of it. It does feel like with some of the work (not many, and they only happen 2x a year and a lot just applies to Consulting, not elsewhere in IBM) at first is a little unnecessary but can easily become a big drag to try get done by the deadlines. As an apprentice it is made 10x easier with the contract and resources at the ready so not much to state here. Really though I think these are more just trivial personal matters that I haven't seen much of the rest of the real world of work (in tech) yet so take these as a pinch of salt. There are overwhelmingly far more positives than negatives and if you want to go to uni but not be in debt/or not sure if you have the grades for it then Level 4 with IBM is the BEST place to be. You cannot find any opportunities elsewhere quite like this. I know from experience and word of mouth.

pros: - Work from home. - Just in case if you want to go to office you can sit in any near by IBM office. - Job never gets stale, don't like the project you are in find and join a new one. - Career advancement paths are clear for techies and consultants. - Training and certification is encouraged. - Work life balance: My managers understand that I have a family.

There are several business resource groups for sub communities like LGBTQIA+, Asian, Black and also for different regions like NYC etc, which is a great way to meet like-minded IBMers. review_title: Good to learn - Bad work life balance
pros: Depends on the project you are in. Some projects will give you enough time to apply your knowledge and also learn new things. But most of the projects/managers will have unrealistic expectations. They won't hesitate to ask you to build the whole testing framework within one or two weeks.
cons: Everything depends on your project manager. They can give you work from home or call you to office everyday. They will often ask you to stretch and work for 12+ hours without any added benefits. IBM policy clearly states that if you work on weekend, more hours, you should be given comp-off. But it's only on paper. People don't even know what is comp-off here.

review_title: This role assists clients in the selection, implementation, and production support of application packaged solutions.
pros: Many of IBM's employees are remote workers. This comes with both pro and con qualities. The pro's are obvious, less gas used, less time spent in travel, flexible work hours, etc. The only real con is isolation. The division I work in has been extremely generous with flex time, allowing me to work when I want
cons: IBM is such a huge organization that sometimes getting through the red tape to accomplish something is horrible. Most everything in my division is driven by customer dollars, leaving little room for R&D type activities.

review_title: Great Pros, some points to improve
pros:
- The amount of training available is unbelievable, with a lot of internal platforms with complete courses, plus external sources like Udemy for every IBMer.
- The culture is great, people are normally respectful and positive, there is a lot of focus on inclusion and diversity
- work remotely
- Management is often well prepared, as they participate in extensive testing and preparation
cons:
- Salary could be way better
- Depending on your area of expertise, it is difficult to find good projects that are in line with the agreed career goals.
- Project Instability on the consulting business. Not really IBM's fault (often Customers change direction, pause or cancel the project), but it is still a con when someone needs to change projects every couple of months. It does not seem to be a general thing, though.

pros: I really enjoy working at IBM. Unlike other large companies, there is a special, inclusive and diverse culture here. Colleagues are there for each other and really work as a team. The hierarchy is open to many topics and new ideas. Of course, there are always exceptions, but overall I consider myself very lucky to work here.
cons: IBM is a large company that is constantly evolving. If you tend to dislike change and many contacts, it may not be the right company.

job_title: Application Developer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: - Deeply Inclusive and Ethical culture! I am allowed to wear my goth getup to the office, we had a coworker start gender transition and someone from HR held a meeting with us to go over how to support our coworker during their transition and avoid any awkward conversations. LOVE IT! - My bosses definitely ask for their bottom lines, but we are encouraged to keep a healthy mental state. My due dates have been pushed without argument if I was having a hard time with my depression. - Lots of vacation days, designated holidays, and sick leave. No overtime to PTO options for my position. Life and health insurance is run of the mill, retirement is nice and we have an option to discuss our retirement investments with a financial management team quarterly for FREE. Daycare assistance, adoption assistance, and wonderful education assistance. - There are documents available to show you just what you need to do for raises, bonuses, and promotions. There is a small amount left to discretion, but you will always have proof to argue your worth. You have the opportunity to switch jobs internally and move from location to location (over years, of course. Not months.) This company is full of opportunity and awesome folks.
cons: - Time zones. You will work on flex time, working a certain amount of hours a week, with whoever you are assigned to work with. Some mornings you will have meetings with offshore teams at 3am, and sometimes you will coordinate deployments at midnight on a Friday. There is usually ample warning, and these terms are kinda negotiable. I have gotten used to quick naps when needed. - Onboarding feels a little silly and lonely. You will be given a LOT of information and then left ALONE for 2 months while you slowly undergo endless onboarding training in addition to your position. I asked for a lot of help, and only got a little. I now mentor folks to try and help alleviate that, but it's rough across most cases.

review_title: Great work culture; unsteady on product execution.
pros: Review for Product development division: Great work culture. You are respected for what you are. One of the few places I have worked that had a high collection of brilliant and good natured humans. In the long term, pay is catching up with the product development industry.
cons: Middle management keeps on changing product directions - sometimes too often. This leads to slow execution velocity. This can be frustrating at times. Like other companies - they don't have a robust developer advocacy program, so don't expect the product/feature you worked on will ever be seen by the customer.

pros:
Work life balance is amazing.

It’s an easy job where many people seem to be coasting to retirement.
cons:
The work life balance is amazing unfortunately because you’re never doing anything of value. 

The work can involve ancient technology and dealing with people who love that ancient stuff can be tedious. IBM loves the mainframe and really anything clients get stuck with as that’s the model. Make it hard for clients to leave. 

Whatever you do there’s 5 other teams that do the same thing and there is no central strategy for dealing with it. Everyone who does the same thing does it slightly differently. This leads to projects with a lot of overlap. 

Pay isn’t very good and bonuses are a joke. No one comes here for money though.

They have a lot of lawsuits ranging from not paying commissions to age discrimination to being dishonest about revenue and no one seems to think they’re not all valid.

review_title: InnerSource is the way to go!
pros: InnerSource, the use of Open Source Technologies within a company is an exciting new way to get more people involved in Information Technology projects. It helps with career growth, exposure and employee retention. IBM has stepped up our focus on InnerSource and it helps deliver IT Solutions to those who need it quicker.
cons: Unless properly managed it can detract people from their day to day job. We need management buy in to allow their employees to work on InnerSource projects. It is a balancing act, the manager needs to consider the benefit to the employee while insuring that his group delivers on their commitments to the business. So, the measurement / reward system has to consider what a line manager does for InnerSource, for the whole areas good versus what a specific area (on their own) delivers.

review_title: If you are considering applying to this company.. Simply DON´T!!!!!!!
pros: IBM name looks "beautiful" in anyone´s CV.
cons: This is the worst company you can work for: training, tools, managers, benefits, flexibility, etc.. NOTHING is good in this company. It is like they are living in the stone age, treating their employees as slaves, demanding demanding demanding, but not giving anything in return (just the salary, which in any other company could be way higher). It is completely disorganized, from the very beginning you are thrown to "the lions" without a proper training about what your role involves, or what tools you need.. You need to figure it out ALL ON YOUR OWN!! But at the same time your manager will start to demand results (even when you don't have A CLUE about what you need to do because nobody trains you). As a sales person you cover MANY (if not ALL) the products of IBM, which is impossible to learn because there are THOUSANDS of them, but they ask you to talk with any type of clients, like if you are a robot knowing ALL the products of the company. And when seeking for help, nobody knows anything, no even your manager, you can spend a whole day just trying to figure out WHO can take care of a customer request (for example).. People don´t care at all about the customers because IBM itself doesn't care at all about its customers, and even less, about its employees!! Many people have been in the company for many years, even DECADES and they got used to the "culture" of the company which is "Be selfish and work on your own'' - NO collaborative, friendly, fresh environment, it is all the contrary: you need literally to fight with people to get your job done! Many people are like they don't care at all about anything, you could BEG them to get their help (my job depends on many people), and it is like talking to the wall!!! And the worst part is that MANAGERS know all the situation and do NOTHING to try to improve the environment.. Many managers that I am aware of, and my own manager too, have no clue about what they are doing, they are very restrictive, micromanaging, don´t listen to their people, and everything needs to be done THEIR way.. Trying to control EVERYTHING!!!! Two days MANDATORY we need to go to the office: Days that THEY chose, not the ones that you want. No flexibility in working from another country, and they recently informed us about some "IRISH NEWS" which states that supposedly Sales people cannot work a SINGLE DAY in another country... They really think their employees are not smart enough to KNOW this is just a BIG LIE!!! and instead of saying: IBM DOES NOT WANT you to work from another country, they just make a laughable LIE and pretend all of us fall for it. Additionally, the offices in Dublin are very very far from the city, there is no easy way to get there and they have an "IBM Bus" that you need to PAY: 6 euro return ticket!!!! (FOR REAL!!!) - It is just unbelievable... Once in the office NOTHING is for free, you even need to pay for a cup of coffee or tea!!! But even like that, they demand people to go to the office! (What incentive would we have to go to the office???). To top it all, for Christmas Celebration they prepare a "special meal" which WE HAD TO PAY!! (Of course... In IBM NOTHING is for free!!!). And we didn´t receive ANYTHING, no appreciation card, no bonuses, no dinner, nothing.. It is a very MEAN company!! Any new hire starts with enthusiasm, excitement, wanting to give their best, very happy... and it is just matter of few months (or even few weeks) and you can see how IBM changes people´s behaviour, they either leave the company or become bitter, selfish, angry in order to survive in the "HEALTHY CULTURE" of the company.. In a nutshell, if you are considering applying to this company.. Simply DON´T!!!

review_title: Good place to work if you have a good manager
job_title: Robotic Process Automation (RPA) Developer in Bratislava
pros: If you have the support of a good manager then IBM is a great place to work. A good manager will help you grow and learn the skills you need to push in the direction you want to go.
cons: There are many bad managers in IBM, promotions or rotations are routinely blocked if the manager of the team you're on doesn't want to lose you (many would rather you quit than "lose" you to another team). I've seen many colleagues be told blatant lies about rules regarding rotations. The Q2C organisation in particular is the home to this kind of behaviour. I've seen that CIO and Accounting are much more professional organisations.

review_title: Good place to work - Improving all the time
job_title: Chief Technology Officer (CTO) in Hartford, CT
pros:
- Things improving with the new CEO -Arvind Krishna who arrived in 2020, he is working hard to improve the culure (much more open communication and is willing to change) 
 - Infllux of many new & younger people is improving the company , many great people are joining IBM from ouside and being promoted, improving the company. 
 - Kyndryl spin-off has improved IBM and allowed them to be more focused on Cloud and Cognitive, Data & Analytics and other high growth areas. 
 - IBM's image is improving every year thanks to Arvind and many new executives in senior management team.
 - Management is focused on diversity & inclusion - more than lip service, they are really doing it, improving the company culture
 - Arvind has developed many new partnerships - realizes that IBM can no longer do everything on their own - this is the right strategy
 - Employee morale has been consistently improving since 2020
cons:
- Still working to improve customers' impression of IBM's cloud capabilities 
- IBM still has a credibility issue with many of their customers due to previous leadership (prior to Arvind), this is a work in progress that will take some time
- Like all of the IT Industry, work hours are very demanding.

pros:
1. Flexible work from home time.
2. Team is small but it depends on the product in IBM cloud, so there will be so much to work on and learn.
3. Many new and widely used coding languages and technologies are used within same team, this helps in learning and developing new skills.
4. Internet broadband reimbursement.
5. Lot of learning opportunities.
6. My team is really good, manager and lead understands your concerns and will help you to resolve them.
7. Management is good.
8. Work life and personal life balance is good so far. I cannot compare with other companies as this is mostly depends on the employee.
cons:
1. Perks and benifits are okay and way less to other cloud providers companies.
2. Food on site is not good. Not worth for what you pay😕 
3. Three coffees or tea will be free after that you will have to pay.
4. You get UPS and headset which is okay.
5. The laptop charge holds good for 3 to 4hrs with continuous work. The UPS back up is 30mins max which was given by company. Bangalore power cuts are way more than this in summer. This doesn't match up at all. But still we can goto office during these times. This was a major issue during covid lockdowns. I had to buy better UPS by myself. There is no reimbursement for anything other than broadband as of now.

Senior management is not diverse in ethnicity and backgrounds.

Visibility to leadership.

Collaboration of employees across the globe.
Top tier education for employees - dedicated time to learn and grow your skills. 
Mentorship / shadow opportunity are abundant and encouraged.
Extremely inclusive culture in finance. Diverse workforce up until senior management.
cons:
Outdated internal financial systems/tools.
Average pay (has been better in recent years).
Some population that does not adapt easily to change.
Uncertain direction for some parts of the business. Kyndryl spin off has helped tremendously.
Senior management is not diverse in ethnicity and backgrounds.

job_title: User Experience Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Work/life balance
Great design managers
Diversity within leadership; race, gender, sexual orientation, etc.
cons:
The company values engineering over design, making it challenging to create the best work; the company relies too heavily on the easiest path of doing things. 80% of the time, the response is, "We can't build that."
"MVP" is a term that's used too often as an excuse and a crutch for delivering mediocre products and features that don't address what users asked for.
Bureaucracy when trying to accomplish even the most straightforward design goals.
Requirements for designers that don't add value and eat up time such as mandatory 40 hours per year of online courses and quarterly Design Jams.
Uncompetitive compensation.

cons: Long short story, bringing the edge technologies has a great dependency on who is too much above you, this person doesn't understand your business need for that specific client with that specific business problem. review_title: Good benefits and work life balance
job_title: Software Development Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The benefits and salary are good. Work life balance is also good. Work is interesting and it's possible to have a life and a family along with a good high tech job.

Company culture / values / are good. It is an honest, decent company.
cons:
Aside from salary, not much opportunity for participating the company's success. Very few employees get stock options, and bonuses are miniscule, when they come at all.

Most new hiring is being done overseas, as IBM is run by accountants, who think that a developer in one locale is the same as any other, so why not hire the cheapest engineer in the world. This leads to globally distributed teams which don't work very well (get up early to meet with team members in Europe, then stay up late to meet with other team members in India and China -why not?)

The company;s practice of rotating executives every 2 years leads to a lot of dysfunctional teams. Short term decisions are made, because executives know that they won't be around a few years later when the cost of bad decisions comes due.

job_title: Senior Agile Lead in Dallas, TX
pros:
* Smart, helpful, capable peers
* Finally creating momentum towards a more focused approach on Hybrid Cloud and AI (Machine Learning, mostly)
* Best chance of career growth for those in their early 20's to late 30's
cons:
* Traditional command and control thinking from most senior execs, leaders, and managers.
* Brands (owners of various product lines) own the budgets and set the focus too much on "what's in it for IBM" instead of "what's in it for the client".
* 'Agile' is still a buzzword and not applied in consistent or meaningful ways the vast majority of the time. Agile is more than a framework (Scrum, in particular).
* Too much downsizing without seeming regard for the performance of the individuals; large, sweeping Resource Allocations (RAs) = seemingly getting rid of swaths of employees without trying to identify the performance of individuals affected so that we don't lose our best talent.

pros: Very nice people who are eager to help. The starting compensation was fair, not outstanding. Beautiful campus in Armonk with shuttle service.

No bonus until you reach Executive band. Annual raise was 3% - not nearly enough for the amount of work and re-work during quarter close periods. Quick turnarounds for last minute changes during quarter close. Honestly, quarter close is just awful on all fronts! Super stressful and most of it could've been avoided.

review_title: Cautions to recommend IBM for a sales or marketing position
pros: Remote work, for the most part a very ethical company (but google dinobabies), committed to diversity and LGBTQ, adequate pay and benefits, some products are good. Rank and file are good people. Good work life balance and for the most part managers care about their people.
cons:
Micromanagement to the extreme, very little sales manager empowerment, unreasonably focused on metrics and pipeline over actual performance, commitment to many product lines is virtually non existent, too much sales generalization - the expectation is that you may sell dozens or hundreds of unrelated products. Constant territory churn, horrible CRM that is simply used for forecasting and not working with clients. Huge emphasis on "cadence" where everyone has to spend hours each week reviewing deals and next steps with execs. Horrible lead generation and marketing in general.

We could not retain many young successful sellers who were constantly being hired off by more agile and focused competitors with better cultures. Sales can be a tough job and IBM's micromanaging sales culture makes it worse.

IBM is not a bad place to work but could be so much better by modernizing it's sales culture. I would be cautious to recommend this as a place to work. Depending upon your situation it might be great, or not so much.
